title: Defining the various fasting protocols
content: The overnight fast is the standard fast that almost by definition everybody does between dinner and breakfast. Time restricted feeding (TRF) is the idea where you increase that window from just an overnight fast into a slightly longer window. Alternate day fasting (ADF) means that every other day you do something other than eating ad libitum. Intermittent fasting (IF) is undergoing a fast (of at least 24 hours) at some frequency. 5:2 hypocaloric fast is another popular variation of fasting where five days out of the seven-day week you’re eating normally but two days out of the seven-day week (but not successive days), you are typically eating a hypocaloric diet of 400 to 600 calories. Fasting Mimicking Diet (FMD) is a trademarked protocol coined by a company called L-Nutra which sells a prepackaged five-day fast. Prolonged fasting/multiple-day fasting is a true fast is water only (plus minerals) for a period of time (typically three to seven days at a time).

title: Why Peter plans to switch to a 3-day fast once per month in 2020
content: For 2020, Peter plans to switch to a 3-day water-only fast once per month. There will be a more consistent exposure to fasting but at the same time, he may not be going as deep into the physiologic effects of fasting. Peter’s intuition is that 3 days is probably the minimum amount of time needed to hit some of the important physiologic benchmarks such as glycogen depletion which leads to inhibition of mTOR, activation of AMPK, a significant reduction of glucose and insulin that triggers autophagy and the inhibition of senescent cells.

title: How Peter uses his CGM to gain insights into the depth of fast
content: Peter relies heavily on his CGM to give him insights during his fast. He looking for thinking like, what’s the behavior of my glucose at night? When in a fed state, his nighttime glucose can actually be quite erratic and he tends to run the highest glucose at night. When in a fasted state, that erratic nature of glucose tends to vanish by the end of 48 hours (and certainly by the third day of only consuming water). He basically has a flat line of glucose and it’s a very low number, typically in the 60s. The only thing that can make it budge is exercise.

title: Starvation Experiment
content: Subjects were fasted for 40 days on water-only. After a month+, they maintained the blood glucose of about three millimolar which would be in the high 50s. The body is breaking down triglycerides into free fatty acids which are then used to make the ketones. The backbone of that free fatty acid is glycerol which then becomes gluconeogenic substrate. The liver takes that backbone of glycerol (three carbons) and it makes glucose. So even though you’re not eating, you’re still able to make glucose in the liver and the brain is still dependent on glucose even in a fasted state.

title: Supplement Protocol During Fasting
content: Leading up to his 7-day water-only fasts, Peter usually eats a ketogenic diet the week prior as a way to ease the transition into using BHB for energy. Supplement protocol includes Magnesium, Methylated B vitamin complex, Sodium. He does NOT take rapamycin or metformin during a fast. On the three-day fast Peter recently did, he did NOT supplement any sodium at all and felt great. On the seven-day fasts, he’s historically required two additional grams of sodium which he takes in the form of bouillon.

title: Exercise Regimen During a Fast
content: One of the important things during fasting is the preservation of lean mass. It’s pretty easy for the body to undergo some atrophy during a fast, and If we’d like to minimize that it’s [through strength training]. During a fast, the body’s lean mass can undergo some atrophy. The best way to combat that is by strength training (about 30-60 minutes ideally). He attempts to get in at least 60 minutes of strength training per day during a fast.

title: Hunger Levels During a Typical 7-Day Fast
content: When doing 7-day fasts, He always does last meal Saturday, first meal Saturday. From day 2 to day 5 of the fast, Peter says he feels pretty hungry between 12pm-5pm. By day 6, He starts to lose all sense of hunger (medical terms for this is anorexia). Case studies show people have this same complete loss of hunger generally between 7 and 14 days into a fast.

title: Fasting Observations—Core Body Temperature and Thyroid Hormone
content: During a fast, it’s normal to feel a greater perception of being cold. This is because your core body temperature falls. And there’s evidence that by day 3 we’re seeing T3 go way down, and reverse T3 go way up. Your thyroid gland produces a hormone called T4. T4 is inactive so the body has to convert it into either the active hormone which is T3; or the anti-active hormone which is called reverse T3.

title: Fasting Observations—Glucose, BHB, and Hunger Levels
content: BHB levels and glucose levels tend to be highly inversely correlated. So when glucose comes down quickly, BHB will rise quickly. In cases were Peter’s glucose stays “stubbornly” high, BHB levels take longer to come up. What might cause glucose levels to stay up? For Peter, when glucose levels are stubbornly high (i.e., high 80s/low 90s) it’s generally due to cortisol (aka stress).

title: Effects of Stress and Illness on Ketone Production
content: If you’re overly stressed or a little sick, anything that upregulates adrenal output can impair you from making ketones. Chewing a lot of gum sweetened with xylitol, which doesn’t raise glucose at all, can also impair ketone production.

title: Hunger and Ketone Levels
content: Hunger is almost completely abated around day 6 or 7 of fasting, which lines up with ketone levels being in the 5-6 millimolar range. However, there are still times when your ketones are 3-3.5 millimolar and you don’t feel hungry at all. This could be a function of time of day, etc.

title: Starvation Study Findings
content: In a starvation study, glucose keeps dropping and then after a few days basically flatlines. The ketones/BHB is continually increasing for the first three weeks, peaking at ~6 millimoles after 30 days and doesn’t go up much more over the final 10 days. At 10 days, subjects were at 4-4.5 mM.

title: Ketone Levels in Fasting
content: The ketone levels of subjects don’t rise as quickly as those who are at ~5 mM of ketones after a week or less. The more time you spend in ketosis, the better the body gets at using the ketones. This keeps the levels of ketones in the blood from going up continuously and linearly.

title: Fasting and Ketosis
content: People who fast who spend a lot of time in ketosis probably have a different experience than people who fast coming out of a non-ketotic fed state.

title: Sleep Protocol During Fasting
content: Sleep can be tricky during fasting. Some of the “greatest nights of sleep of my entire life” and also some of the “most miserable nights of sleep in my entire life” have been experienced while fasting. When struggling with sleep during fasting, it’s rarely that one is too hungry to fall asleep. It’s usually that one has a hard time staying asleep.

title: Differences Between Men and Women in Fasting
content: Men tend to find fasting a little bit easier, but this might be changing as more and more women go through fasting without a hitch. If a woman is trying to get pregnant, fasting’s a pretty bad strategy because it would likely send a signal that would probably interfere with ovulation and some of the other things that are important to prepare a woman to get pregnant.

title: Breaking a Long Fast
content: Make the first meal a pretty small meal, preferably some cooked vegetables combined with a small amount of protein. If the volume is too big, you might get the hiccups given your stomach has shrunk.

title: Community Support While Fasting
content: Community and support while fasting is important. Doing a fast with others, whether in person or via social media, can be beneficial.
